jury"}]]}]]}]]}]]}],["$","section",null,{"className":"max-w-7xl mx-auto px-4 sm:px-6 lg:px-8 py-8 sm:py-12","children":["$","$L3",null,{"scenario":{"id":"jury-duty","title":"Jury Duty Obligations","icon":"⚖️","category":"Civic Duty","description":"What to know about serving on a jury","rights":[{"title":"Right to Serve Without Employer Retaliation","description":"Your employer cannot punish you, fire you, or threaten you for missing work to serve on a jury. This is a protected civic responsibility. If your employer retaliates, you have legal remedies. Bring your jury summons to your employer to prove your obligation.","source":"Jury Systems Improvement Act (28 U.S.C. § 1875) and State Laws","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to Compensation","description":"Federal courts and most state courts pay jurors a small daily fee. Some employers pay your regular wages during jury duty, but this is not required by law. Compensation varies widely by jurisdiction. Longer trials pay more, though the amounts are typically modest.","source":"28 U.S.C. § 1871 (federal) and State Jury Compensation Laws","stateVariations":[{"state":"UT","note":"Pays $18.50 per day after the first day; first day is unpaid"},{"state":"CA","note":"Pays $15 per day for first 5 days, then $50 per day; private employers may supplement"},{"state":"TX","note":"Pays $6 for the first day, then $40 per day; very low compensation"},{"state":"NY","note":"Pays $40 per day starting day 1; federal courts pay more"},{"state":"FL","note":"Pays $15 per day for first 3 days, $30 per day after"}]},{"title":"Right to Request Postponement","description":"If jury duty is being served at a bad time—you have a critical work project, vacation booked, or family emergency—you can request to reschedule your service to a later date. Courts are often flexible about this. Submit your request promptly with a valid reason; requests made early are more likely to be granted.","source":"State Court Rules and Judicial Discretion","stateVariations":[]},{"title":"Right to Be Excused for Hardship","description":"If jury duty would cause genuine financial or personal hardship—you're the sole caregiver, you're self-employed and would lose significant income, or you have a medical condition—you can petition to be excused. Courts must consider your circumstances. Provide documentation of hardship.","source":"28 U.S.C. § 1869 (federal) and State Hardship Exemption Rules","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Courts are relatively generous with hardship excusals; strong worker protections exist"},{"state":"NY","note":"Hardship excusal available; courts weigh financial and personal circumstances"}]},{"title":"Obligation to Appear","description":"Responding to a jury summons is a legal obligation. Failure to appear without valid excuse can result in contempt of court charges, fines up to $1,000, or jail time in serious cases. If you cannot serve, respond to the summons and explain your situation. Ignoring a summons is not an option.","source":"28 U.S.C. § 1866 and State Court Contempt Laws","stateVariations":[]}]},"availableStates":["CA","FL","NY","TX","UT"]}]}],"$L4"]}],null,"$L5"]}],"loading":null,"isPartial":false}
